Notes: No new policy. Schools are teaching in-person with certain precautions. Ex. teachers wearing masks, students wearing masks.  On 13 January 2022, National Cabinet agreed to a national framework to promote a nationally consistent approach to the ongoing delivery of high-quality education for all students during COVID-19. This framework ensure all schools are open and be able to stay open, with as little disruption from COVID-19 as possible.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220322080316/https://www.dese.gov.au/covid-19/schools  https://archive.ph/mwzii

As of 3 March in the Western Australia region "Level 2" measures are now in effect. More widely, proof of vaccination requirements remain in place for certain businesses and venues (ex. hospitality).     Western Australia Level 2 measures are that:  The 2sqm rule, a maximum of 150 patrons (not including staff) where food and beverages are served, with seated service only, applies to high risk venues including the following:  - Hospitality venues  -Fitness venues  -Entertainment venues (for seated entertainment venues â see below)  -Galleries and museums  -Places of worship  -Hairdressers, beauty services, spas, saunas, tattoo and massage parlours  -Nightclubs     -Convention centres and function centres  -Community, recreation or youth centre facilities  -2sqm rule, up to a limit of 500 patrons, applies to certain other public venues including Perth Zoo, outdoor amusement parks, swimming pools and libraries.  -50 % capacity for specified entertainment venues with fixed seating that faces forward, like cinemas, theatres and concert halls (with seated service only) is permitted as an alternative to the 2sqm rule and 150 patron limit.  50 % capacity for major stadiums with fixed seating, such as Optus Stadium, RAC Arena, HBF Stadium (main area) and HBF Park (with seated service only).    Masks are required for people aged 8 years and over (year 3 and over for schools):  â¢	everywhere indoors, other than in the home  â¢	when on public transport, in taxis and rideshare vehicles  â¢	at major stadiums and organised public gatherings  â¢	at hospitals and residential aged care or disability care facilities    https://archive.ph/4RVp5

As of 3 March in the Western Australia region "Level 2" measures are now in effect where home gatherings are limited to a total of 10 people indoors and outdoors, except weddings and funerals. Vaccination status does not affect this limit.    Most other areas have either no limits or the nearest restriction is on ~100 people (Tasmania).    https://archive.ph/4RVp5  https://archive.ph/MPW9W

No new policy. Public transport in NSW is limited and regional travel from the area is in some cases banned. COVIDSafe capacity on all modes in the NSW region is at 75 percent. Green dots help you to choose the best places to sit and stand on all modes.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220322075858/https://transportnsw.info/covid-19/covid-19-safer-travel-guidance
No lockdowns or lock-ins are currently in place.   https://web.archive.org/web/20220322081916/https://www.health.gov.au/health-alerts/covid-19/restrictions-and-lockdowns  https://archive.ph/uYzIn

As of 3 March in the Western Australia region "Level 2" measures are in effect which allows for safe quarantine-free travel into WA from interstate and overseas, with vaccination and testing requirements on arrival.    Interstate arrivals into WA must:  - have a registered G2G Pass  - be triple dose vaccinated, if eligible; and  - undertake a rapid antigen test (RAT) on arrival (within 12 hours and report any positive result)    Other regional restrictions vary but are more lenient.     https://archive.ph/4RVp5

No new policy. Continuing from 15 December AUS reopens the borders to fully vaccinated international students and Temporary Graduate (subclass 485) visa holders. Continuing policy restricts other travelers to Australia to fully vaccinated Australians and permanent residents.     Fully vaccinated Australian citizens, permanent residents, and eligible visa holders can travel to and from Australia without needing to apply for a travel exemption. All other people who are not fully vaccinated require a travel exemption to enter Australia, and will be subject to applicable state and territory quarantine requirements.     The Australian government requires all individuals traveling to or transiting through Australia, with limited exceptions, to provide evidence of a negative COVID-19 test at time of check-in.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220322084811/https://www.health.gov.au/health-alerts/covid-19/international-travel/inbound  https://web.archive.org/web/20220322084731/https://au.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
No new policy.
No new policy.

No new policy. The Australian Government Department of Health maintains a website with the latest updates on coronavirus status across the nation.   They are also present on social media such as twitter @healthgovau.   https://web.archive.org/web/20220322084134/https://www.health.gov.au/news  http://web.archive.org/web/20220217125811/https://www.health.gov.au/health-alerts/covid-19  http://web.archive.org/web/20220219105227/https://twitter.com/healthgovau?lang=en

No new policy. The Department of Health advises people to get tested when they have COVID-19 symptoms, cold or flu symptoms, are in close contact with someone with COVID-19, or have been advised by  a medical professional.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220322084355/https://www.health.gov.au/health-alerts/covid-19/testing

No new policy. Continuing from 26 April 2020 government contact tracers and regular citizens enter data into an integrated app COVIDSafe.   https://web.archive.org/web/20220322084510/https://www.health.gov.au/health-alerts/covid-19/case-numbers-and-statistics  https://web.archive.org/web/20210921075506/https://www.covidsafe.gov.au/technology.html

As of 3 March in the Western Australia region "Level 2" measures are now in effect where masks must be worn in all indoor public settings.  Masks are required for people aged 8 years and over:  - everywhere indoors, other than in the home  - when on public transport, in taxis and rideshare vehicles  - at major stadiums  - at organised public gatherings: and  - at hospitals and residential aged care or residential disability care facilities    https://archive.ph/4RVp5

No new policy. Everyone in Australia aged 5 years and over is eligible for a free COVID-19 vaccination.   The TGA provisionally approved Pfizer for use in Australia on 25 January 2021 (for 16 years and over), 22 July 2021 (for 12 years and over) and 5 December 2021 (for 5 years and over).  https://web.archive.org/web/20220322082907/https://www.health.gov.au/initiatives-and-programs/covid-19-vaccines/who-can-get-vaccinated  https://web.archive.org/web/20220322083349/https://www.tga.gov.au/covid-19-vaccine-provisional-registrations

No new policies. National policy outlines recommended guidelines to protect the elderly along a three tiered system. The visitation restrictions and guidelines for residential aged care facilities follow social distancing, vaccination and COVID screening norms. It is up to providers to manage and mitigate COVID-19 risks to aged care residents, including the risks that isolation poses to their physical, social and emotional wellbeing. Face-to-face get togethers between residents, family members and friends should be facilitated where they can be undertaken safely and are permitted under public health orders. Residents of an aged care facility have the right to choose to have vaccinations or not.      Under current restrictions, some people cannot visit a residential aged care facility. This includes people who:    - have returned from overseas in the past 14 days  - have been in contact with someone confirmed to have COVID-19 in the past 14 days  - are unwell, including with a fever or symptoms of acute respiratory illness (such as a cough, sore throat, runny nose, shortness of breath)  - need isolation or quarantine (unless directed by and managed per the direction of the local public health unit).    https://web.archive.org/web/20220322082432/https://www.health.gov.au/node/18602/coronavirus-covid-19-advice-for-people-in-residential-aged-care-facilities-and-visitors  https://web.archive.org/web/20210415104420/https://www.health.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/2020/11/coronavirus-covid-19-national-aged-care-guidance-escalation-tiers-and-aged-care-provider-responses.pdf

No new policy. Continued from 13 September 2021, everyone in Australia aged 12 years and over is eligible for a free COVID-19 vaccination.     It appears that starting on the 8th of November people over 18 will be eligible for a booster shot (6 months after their completion of the second dosis).    https://web.archive.org/web/20211201170746/https://www.health.gov.au/initiatives-and-programs/covid-19-vaccines/getting-your-vaccination/booster-doses    https://web.archive.org/web/20210916120513/https://www.health.gov.au/initiatives-and-programs/covid-19-vaccines/getting-vaccinated-for-covid-19/when-will-i-get-a-covid-19-vaccine    https://web.archive.org/web/20211004191741/https://www.health.gov.au/initiatives-and-programs/covid-19-vaccines/who-can-get-vaccinated

Phase 2 of reintroducing in-person learning for Bruneian students has commenced on January 17, 2022.    Originally,  "The first phase will begin on January 3, 2022.     The minister explained that in-person teaching and learning for secondary students in Year 10 and Year 11 will be conducted five times a week, including special needs students from Priority Level 1 and 2. Whereas those in Priority Level 3 will only have to attend their physical classes once a week.     For Year 12 and 13 students, as well as Priority Level 1 and 2, and special need students will also undergo face-to-face teaching and learning five times a week, while once a week in-person classes for Priority Level 3 students.     âMeanwhile, teaching and learning for the remaining students will be made via online or Home Learning Pack (HLP). The first phase is planned to be carried out for at least two weeks whereby the transition towards the second phase depending if there is no increase in the spread of serious cases of infections among the students, teachers and staff as well as on the advice of the COVID-19 Steering Committeeâ, the minister explained.     The minister shared that the second phase is expected to begin on January 17, 2022. However, its implementation will depend on the current Covid-19 situation as well.     In the second phase, said the minister, in-person lessons will be carried out five times a week for students who have completed two doses of COVID-19 vaccines and the increased school capacity from 40 to 100 per cent. This is to be implemented for secondary school students from Year 7 to 11, including special need students in Priority Level 1 and 2. Those in Priority Level 3 will have to attend their physical classes thrice a week, and Year 12 and 13 students, including special needs in Priority Level 1 and 2. Classes for special needs students in Priority Level 3 will be carried out thrice a week.     Lessons for students aged 5 to 11 who have yet to receive their vaccination will continue via online and HLP.     âStudents who continue to have difficulties with online learning will be continued to be supported by the school through the provision of HLPâ, the minister stated. "    Additionally, from the frst Scoop report,   "Only fully vaccinated teachers and students can return to primary and secondary schools, sixth form centres and higher education institutions.    Some 98 percent of teachers are fully jabbed while 80 percent of students aged 12-17 have received two vaccine doses, according to education ministry figures.    All double-vaxxed students, teachers and non-teaching staff are still required to undergo antigen rapid tests once a week in the first stage of school reopening."    â    "Toddlers aged 3 to 4 can head back to kindergartens from January 17, the education minister said Wednesday.    Joining the COVID-19 news conference, Dato Hj Hamzah Hj Sulaiman said in-person lessons will be allowed for preschoolers five times a week, but attendance at kindergartens is capped at 30 percent.    To ensure the safety of preschoolers who are not authorised to receive the vaccine against COVID, only kindergartens that meet health requirements can reopen.    Kindergarten pupils will also be required to wear face masks and undergo antigen rapid tests once a week, with only those producing negative results permitted to attend in-person classes.    The minister said parents and guardians of the children must be fully jabbed and show proof of vaccination.    Double-vaccinated Year 7-9 pupils will also return to classrooms next week after a five-month hiatus due to the COVID-19 pandemic, joining Year 10-13 students who were the first group to resume face-to-face classes earlier this month."    "Brunei is still awaiting the arrival of Pfizer vaccines to inoculate children aged 5-11, who are expected to be the last group to return to schools."    See the Scoop's report, entitled "International travel to resume in January, schools to reopen in stages as Brunei enters âearly endemic phase", archived at https://archive.vn/uA4rP#selection-1681.0-1681.129  See the Scoop's report, entitled "Child care centres set to reopen from January 17", archived at https://archive.vn/WZHR9  See the Brunei Post's report, entitled "School reopening, in-person learning to start in stages", archived at https://archive.vn/frKFF

No change. Public health measures enacted under the 'early endemic phase' has been extended to 14 March.    Business premises can operate to 75 percent or 300-people capacity, whichever is smaller, from 15 December.    "From Wednesday, all people, regardless of vaccination status, will be allowed to enter public premises or attend public events.  However, unvaccinated individuals are required to undergo ART testing at accredited ART Centres. Each test result is valid for two days.  Children under 18 who are unvaccinated or partially vaccinated will be allowed to enter premises without the need for ART testing, provided that they are accompanied by a fully vaccinated adult.  Business and public premises will be allowed to hold 75 percent of their capacity, but not more than 300 people. The rule applies to:     Restaurants, cafÃ©s, food courts, markets and food stalls, cinemas, arcades, indoor playgrounds, beauty establishments, and music schools.  All indoor and outdoor sports, fitness and recreational facilities. (Only training is allowed, no sports competitions.)    Museums, galleries, libraries and senior citizens centres. (Opening hours are restricted to 8am-2pm.)   Government offices and service counters. "    Additionally, the civil service will return to normal in-person working and standard working hours.  "In the early endemic phase, civil servants will fully return to the office and normal working hours will be reinstated from 7.45am to 12.15pm and from 1.30pm to 4.30pm."    The Scoop's report, archived at https://archive.vn/uA4rP#selection-1561.0-1627.41  The Scoop's report about the extension of the early endemic phase, archived at https://archive.vn/H6ZFO

No change. Public health measures enacted under the 'early endemic phase' has been extended to 14 March.    "Public venues can increase capacity to 75%  As Brunei moves into the early endemic phase, the government also announced further easing of restrictions that will come into effect on December 15, 2021 and last until January 14, 2022.   During this period, wearing of face masks and use of the Bruhealth contact tracing app will still be mandatory, and the 10pm to 4am curfew will still be in place.   From Wednesday, all people, regardless of vaccination status, will be allowed to enter public premises or attend public events.  However, unvaccinated individuals are required to undergo ART testing at accredited ART Centres. Each test result is valid for two days.  Children under 18 who are unvaccinated or partially vaccinated will be allowed to enter premises without the need for ART testing, provided that they are accompanied by a fully vaccinated adult.  Business and public premises will be allowed to hold 75 percent of their capacity, but not more than 300 people. The rule applies to:     Restaurants, cafÃ©s, food courts, markets and food stalls, cinemas, arcades, indoor playgrounds, beauty establishments, and music schools.  All indoor and outdoor sports, fitness and recreational facilities. (Only training is allowed, no sports competitions.)  Museums, galleries, libraries and senior citizens centres. (Opening hours are restricted to 8am-2pm.)  Government offices and service counters.     Members of the public are permitted to host large gatherings such as weddings, but attendance is limited to 75 percent of the venue capacity or not more than 300 people  â whichever is the smaller number. Buffet services are still not allowed, except for dome serving, and distribution of packaged meals is encouraged instead."    The Scoop's report, archived at https://archive.vn/uA4rP  The Scoop's report about the extension of the early endemic phase, archived at https://archive.vn/H6ZFO

(Opening hours are restricted to 8am-2pm.)  Government offices and service counters.     Members of the public are permitted to host large gatherings such as weddings, but attendance is limited to 75 percent of the venue capacity or not more than 300 people  â whichever is the smaller number. Buffet services are still not allowed, except for dome serving, and distribution of packaged meals is encouraged instead."    The Scoop's report, archived at https://archive.vn/uA4rP  The Scoop's report about the extension of the early endemic phase, archived at https://archive.vn/H6ZFO

No change. Public health measures enacted under the 'early endemic phase' has been extended to 14 March.    With the transition to the early endemic phase, the Ministry of Transport and Infocommunications have advised that transport vehicles are now limited to 75% capacity, up from 50% previously.    "2. Similarly with Public Transport such as buses, taxis and e-hailing services as well as transport of mining boats, passenger boats and passenger ships where the number of passengers is increased to 75% of the previous total passenger capacity of 50% (excluding drivers) and ensure the existence of social incarceration measures. This means that the vehicle seat capacity and number of passengers for taxis and e-Hailing vehicles such as DART service is according to the vehicle seat capacity for example the vehicle seat capacity is 5 people and the passenger limit is 3 people and so on if the capacity is 7 people and the passenger limit is 4 people."    See the Ministry of Transport and Infocommunications's press release, archived in Malay, at https://archive.vn/vfs6b (see point 2 under SOP Pembukaan Sekolah Memandu dan Pengangkutan Awam)  The Scoop's report about the extension of the early endemic phase, archived at https://archive.vn/H6ZFO

No change. Public health measures enacted under the 'early endemic phase' has been extended to 14 March.    Measures have been eased with the commencement of the early endemic phase, with the public allowed to host events up to 75% capacity/300 people, and the civil service returning to work.    However, night-time curfews are still in force and extended to 14th February, with the curfew remaining but shortened to 12 to 4am from 15 January. Up to this date, Brunei's night-time curfews remain from 10pm to 4am. No change. The only country-specific exception to the total travel ban is the Reciprocal Green Lane and Vaccinated Travel Lane with Singapore. Other foreigners can only enter Brunei under specific essential travel circumstances (see below). Although a green travel list comprising other countries such as the United Kingdom and Australia was originally envisioned for the lifting on restriction on non-essential inbound travel on Jan 1, 2022, this has now been scrapped due to concerns over the Omicron variant.    As per the US Embassy in Brunei's website, last updated on 22 Feb, foreigners that do not have a valid reason to enter are banned from entering.    Entry and Exit Requirements:    Are U.S. citizens permitted to enter?  No.          Effective September 15, 2020, foreign citizens who meet certain requirements may enter Brunei for essential travel only.  All other foreign citizens are barred from entering or transiting Brunei by air, land, or sea.  Visit the website of the Prime Ministerâs Office for the latest information.          Citizens, permanent residents, and other residents of Brunei, including foreign citizens who hold a green identity card, require approval from the Prime Ministerâs Office in order to leave the country. This policy does not apply to tourists or other visitors who do not hold Bruneian government-issued identity cards.  Residents may apply for permission to leave the country by completing an online application at the website of the Prime Ministerâs Office.          Travelers should be prepared for additional travel restrictions to be put into effect with little to no advance notice. Visit the website of the Brunei Ministry of Health for the latest information.      Is a negative COVID-19 test (PCR and/or serology) required for entry?  Yes.          Visit the website of the Prime Ministerâs Office for more information regarding Bruneiâs pre-departure testing requirements.      Are health screening procedures in place at airports and other ports of entry?  Yes.          Brunei International Airport implemented temperature screening requirements for all visitors. Temperature screening is also required at all land and sea-based points of entry into Brunei.      Extensions of social visits, professional visits, or business visits while already in Brunei can be made directly with the Visa, Visit and Diplomatic Section, Department of Immigration and National Registration.  Visit the website of the Department of Immigration and National Registration for more information.    ---    Per the Entry Travel Pass requirements, last updated 02 Oct 2020,    The Entry Travel Pass may be issued for the following individuals:  â¢ Essential business travel (including official travel)  â¢ Students  â¢ Individual primarily here for the purpose of medical treatment  â¢ Compassionate and other special circumstances, such as parents, spouse, or other  immediate family members of Brunei Citizens or Residents.  Applications will be reviewed for considerations on a case-to-case basis by authorities.    See the [US Embassy in Brunei's website](https://archive.vn/EPGK9), archived at https://archive.vn/EPGK9  See the Prime Minister Office's guidelines on Entry Travel Pass applications, archived on Dropbox at https://www.dropbox.com/s/j0vr278nkt9dfh4/BRN-20201002-PMO-Guidelines_EntryTravelPassApp.pdf  See the Scoop's report, entitled "Brunei backtracks on plans to lift travel curbs over Omicron concerns", archived at https://archive.vn/8lobr

No changes/deviation; Brunei continues to maintain a systematic, coordinated public campaign re: COVID.    The government continues to maintain an overall website where citizens can access any information related to COVID.   https://archive.vn/PwOIW    There is also an overall site on the Ministry of Health's website pertaining to Covid-19 vaccination (the programme, FAQ, public health messaging).  https://archive.vn/5UFPG    The Ministry of Health continues to update COVID case numbers almost daily. Although there are no update on the Ministry of Health's website this week, this is available on https://www.healthinfo.gov.bn

No change.    As per the US Embassy in Brunei's website, last updated on 22 Feb,    Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Brunei?  Yes.  If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours?  Yes.  Members of the public who need to undergo a swab test for any reason are advised to go to the Sports Complex, Raja Isteri Pengiran Anak Saleha (RIPAS) Hospital, or other health centers where testing is provided.  The testing fee for foreigners is BND $200 [sic, current cost as per Brunei's Ministry of Health is BND $50].  More information is available here.  Test results will be delivered through SMS.    See the US Embassy in Brunei's website, archived at https://archive.vn/EPGK9  See the Ministry of Health press release on testing cost (22 May), archived at https://archive.vn/kU9pS

No changes.    On 07 August, Brunei detected its first local Covid-19 cases in over a year, all of which were unlinked to previously-known imported cases. Hence, Brunei has decided to tighten Covid measures, including instituting mandatory mask measures.    Per the press release of 07 Aug by the Ministry of Health,    "Meanwhile, to address the concerns on the spread of Delta variant around the world, including in Brunei Darussalam, the Ministry of Health would also like to inform the public on the changes in the face mask guidelines:    1. Face masks are required be worn at all times, especially indoors or in crowded places either indoor or outdoor.  2. Face mask must cover the wearer's nose and mouth.  3. This directive is applicable to all individuals regardless of their vaccination status."    As per the US Embassy in Brunei's website, last updated on 22 Feb,    "Face masks are mandatory at all times in all indoor and outdoor spaces."    This advice is confirmed in a press conference conducted by the Minister at the Prime Minister's Office, YB Dato Dr Hj Mohd Amin, on 12th December, "During this period, wearing of face masks and use of the Bruhealth contact tracing app will still be mandatory, and the 10pm to 4am curfew will still be in place."    See the Ministry of Health's press release, archived at https://archive.vn/C5fBL  See the US Embassy in Brunei's website, archived at https://archive.vn/EPGK9  See the Scoop's report, archived at https://archive.vn/uA4rP

Face masks are required be worn at all times, especially indoors or in crowded places either indoor or outdoor.  2. Face mask must cover the wearer's nose and mouth.  3. This directive is applicable to all individuals regardless of their vaccination status." Hence, Brunei has decided to tighten Covid measures, including instituting mandatory mask measures.    Per the press release of 07 Aug by the Ministry of Health,    "Meanwhile, to address the concerns on the spread of Delta variant around the world, including in Brunei Darussalam, the Ministry of Health would also like to inform the public on the changes in the face mask guidelines:    1. Face masks are required be worn at all times, especially indoors or in crowded places either indoor or outdoor.  2. Face mask must cover the wearer's nose and mouth.  3. This directive is applicable to all individuals regardless of their vaccination status."    As per the US Embassy in Brunei's website, last updated on 17 Mar,    "Face masks are mandatory at all times in all indoor and outdoor spaces."    This advice is confirmed in a press conference conducted by the Minister at the Prime Minister's Office, YB Dato Dr Hj Mohd Amin, on 12th December, "During this period, wearing of face masks and use of the Bruhealth contact tracing app will still be mandatory, and the 10pm to 4am curfew will still be in place."    See the Ministry of Health's press release, archived at https://archive.vn/C5fBL  See the US Embassy in Brunei's website, archived at https://archive.ph/dgjiE  See the Scoop's report, archived at https://archive.vn/uA4rP

No changes.    Brunei's Phase 3 of its Vaccination Strategy, for individuals aged 18 years and above, commenced on 05 July. "[Individuals] who wish to get the COVID-19 vaccinations during Phase 3 are required to reserve a slot".    Vaccinations have also been rolled out to adolescents aged 12 to 17 from November 8, utilising the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine.    Booster shots have been available to the general public since 17 December. No change in policy since last iteration.    Additionally, under Brunei's Vaccination Strategy, senior citizens of age 60 and above belong to Phase 1, alongside Bruneians studying abroad and frontliners.    The advice for elderly people to be protected via vaccinations was reiterated on 07 Aug, when Brunei first detected its first local transmission cases in over a year. "Individuals who have not yet received COVID-19 vaccination especially those at high risk such as the elderly and those with chronic diseases are advised to reserve an vaccination slot as soon as possible. Walk-ins at vaccination centres will only be allowed for senior citizens aged 60 and above or individuals with special needs."    See https://web.archive.org/web/20210111022516/http://www.moh.gov.bn/Lists/Latest%20news/NewDispForm.aspx?ID=727  See also, Brunei's Vaccination Strategy, archived on Dropbox, at https://www.dropbox.com/s/yri6djij3ieblma/BRN-202103__-MOH-VaccinationStrategyV2.pdf  See also, IMF's summary on the vaccination groups under "Brunei: Reopening of the Economy", archived at https://web.archive.org/web/20220212053517/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19  See the Ministry of Health's press release dated 07 Aug, archived at https://archive.vn/C5fBL

The policy in Tianjin is still valid.   On January 12, according to the development of the epidemic situation, Tianjin's universities, middle and primary schools will enter the winter vacation from now on, and all schools will be closed for management.   https://archive.vn/qd6Om  https://archive.vn/OQHko

2022-02-21, Chengmai County, Hainan Province, pointed out that from 21 onwards, schools and kindergartens at all levels in the county area of Jinjiang Town are closed, schools and kindergartens at all levels in the county area of Jinjiang Town are closed, students and staff are suspended from returning to school specific return time to be determined.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220301044251/https://wappass.baidu.com/static/captcha/tuxing.html?ak=572be823e2f50ea759a616c060d6b9f1&backurl=https%3A%2F%2Fmbd.baidu.com%2Fnewspage%2Fdata%2Flandingsuper%3Fthird%3Dbaijiahao%26baijiahao_id%3D1725816067922468158%26c_source%3Dduedge&timestamp=1646109769&signature=8def470f9f6de03d0993431b39abdba9

The policy in Tianjin is still valid.   On January 12, Tianjin demanded the closure of general public places, the suspension of the opening of various religious places, and the suspension of collective religious activities. https://archive.vn/nyKzv

The policy in Tianjin is still valid.   On January 12, Tianjin issued the "Proposal for Epidemic Prevention and Control in Rural Areas of the City", which clearly stated that the holding of wedding ceremonies, brief funerals, and banquets would be suspended, and gathering activities such as village meetings and literary and art gatherings would be suspended.   https://archive.vn/yoN5k  https://archive.ph/5vv2o

The Tianjin Municipal Health and Wellness Commission noted on February 19, 2022 that during the epidemic outbreak and epidemic, the city and district epidemic prevention and control commands clearly issued orders prohibiting gathering activities such as dining and entertainment.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220227135740/http://www.tj.gov.cn/sy/ztzl/tjsfyyqfkzt/sjzcwj/202202/t20220219_5808539.html

The policy in Xi'an is still valid.  In Xi'an, buses, taxis, online car-hailing, subways, bus lines and other means of transportation have resumed operations in an all-round way, and drivers and passengers need to take personal protection since Jan.24th.   On 23 January, 2022, the full load ratio of rail transit and ground bus is adjusted to 75% in Beijing Fengtai District.     https://archive.vn/p0JIF  https://archive.vn/Q3pUA

The policy in Xi'an is still valid.  As for Xi'an, people in low-risk areas outside the city can return with a 48-hour negative nucleic acid test certificate, a communication big data itinerary card, and Xi'an "One Code Pass" with a green code.     https://archive.vn/p0JIF#selection-213.13-221.37

On 2022-02-18, the People's Government of Zhuhai stated that all flights departing from Zhuhai Airport to Beijing will be cancelled from 18 February onwards.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220301041241/https://www.gd.gov.cn/gdywdt/zwzt/yqfkzccs/dszc/content/post_3496929.html

The Tianjin Municipal Health and Wellness Commission pointed out on February 19, 2022 that if you are in a closed, controlled or precautionary zone, please be sure to take the initiative to report to your community and cooperate with the community's preventive and control measures, and do not leave without permission, let alone go out and gather.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220227135740/http://www.tj.gov.cn/sy/ztzl/tjsfyyqfkzt/sjzcwj/202202/t20220219_5808539.html

2022-02-28, the Jiangxi Provincial People's Government pointed out that it had arranged for special staff to conduct a "two-code" joint check of the health code and the vaccination record of the new coronavirus for those who entered, and that those who had not received the new coronavirus vaccination had to verify the registration of their names, telephone numbers, residential addresses and other information before they could enter.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220301024213/http://www.jiangxi.gov.cn/art/2022/2/28/art_61056_3872506.html

Individuals who are currently receiving the first and second dose of the COVID-19 vaccines will be administered with the Pfizer COVID-19 vaccine. The Ministry of Health and Medical Services reminds the public that currently there are no stocks of AstraZeneca vaccine in the country therefore, Pfizer is offered for primary series.    Additionally, both, Pfizer and Moderna COVID-19 vaccines are administered as booster doses to individuals aged 18 years and above. Individuals become eligible for the booster dose 5 months after they have received their 2nd dose.  Eligible individuals are encouraged to get their booster doses to maintain maximum and longer-lasting protection against severe consequences from COVID-19.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220307084939/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

The Ministry of Education, Culture, Research and Technology has issued Circular No. 2/2022 on Discretion Towards the Implementation of the four-minister joint decree on schooling during the COVID-19 pandemic. The circular stipulates that those areas where PPKM level 2 are implemented may limit face-to-face schooling to 50% of the class capacity.    http://web.archive.org/web/20220311142913/https://indonesien.ahk.de/en/infocenter/news/news-details/covid-19-developments-in-indonesia

In Java and Bali, areas under level 4 protocols allow non-essential and essential industries to operate on-site at 25 and 50-percent capacity, respectively. Level 3 restrictions permit on-site workforce caps of up to 50 percent in most industries and 75 percent in export-oriented industries. Level 2 curbs allow all sectors to operate on-site at a maximum of 75-percent capacity. Under level 1 protocols, all sectors can run at full capacity.    http://web.archive.org/web/20220317211252/https://crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/03/indonesia-officials-further-shorten-quarantine-for-fully-vaccinated-international-travelers-as-of-march-9-update-108

Minister of Home Affairs Tito Karnavian has issued Minister of Home Affairs Instruction (Inmendagri) No. 8/2022 on the prevention and handling of COVID-19 during the Mandalika MotoGP in Pertamina Mandalika International Street Circuit, West Nusa Tenggara 2022. The instruction stipulates a maximum of 100,000 on-site viewers, and a maximum capacity of 10 percent for the festival grounds. All on-site viewers, racers, attendants, crew and officials must also be already fully vaccinated and present a negative PCR test result that is valid for 2x24 hour or a negative Antigen test result that is valid for 1x24 hour    http://web.archive.org/web/20220311142913/https://indonesien.ahk.de/en/infocenter/news/news-details/covid-19-developments-in-indonesia

As of March 9, officials have lifted the pre-departure testing rule for fully vaccinated domestic travelers on air, sea, and land routes. Unvaccinated travelers must provide a negative PCR test taken within 72 hours or a RAT test taken within 24 hours before departure. All air and sea travelers must also register on the Health Alert Card (eHAC) mobile application before travel. Officials advise passengers to download the PeduliLindungi contact tracing application.    http://web.archive.org/web/20220317211252/https://crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/03/indonesia-officials-further-shorten-quarantine-for-fully-vaccinated-international-travelers-as-of-march-9-update-108

The government will officially pilot its three-day quarantine policy for vaccinated international travelers entering Indonesia starting March 1, 2022. Coordinating Minister of Maritime Affairs and Investment Luhut Binsar Pandjaitan said the decision was taken in consideration of the relatively low rate of daily cases but also the relatively high rate of deaths in Indonesia compared to other countries that no longer require quarantine.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220301200119/https://indonesien.ahk.de/en/infocenter/news/news-details/covid-19-developments-in-indonesia

Indonesian authorities are adjusting international travel curbs as of March 9. Fully vaccinated arrivals must isolate for one day, regardless of whether they have received booster doses. Such passengers must undergo COVID-19 tests before departure to Indonesia, upon arrival, as well as on the third day of their stay. On-arrival visas and quarantine-free travel are available for select travelers to Bali from March 7.    http://web.archive.org/web/20220317211252/https://crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/03/indonesia-officials-further-shorten-quarantine-for-fully-vaccinated-international-travelers-as-of-march-9-update-108

The Ministry of Finance has issued Minister of Finance Regulation No. 3/PMK.03/2022 on Tax Incentive for Taxpayers affected by the COVID-19 pandemic. The Regulation stipulates the extension of the prevailing tax incentive on income tax, import tax on certain importers, as well as final income tax for construction services. The import tax incentive is effective until June 30, 2022, while the income tax and the construction services final income tax incentives is effective until the June 2022 tax period.    http://web.archive.org/web/20220311142913/https://indonesien.ahk.de/en/infocenter/news/news-details/covid-19-developments-in-indonesia

No change to previous policy.  The following measures now apply to all prefectures under priority measures: Require closing restaurants and retail from 9PM and to refrain from serving alcohol after 8PM. Restaurants may continue to serve patrons up to a limit of 4 people per table and may serve groups greater than 4 if proof of vaccination is shown. For all other businesses remote work from home is encouraged when possible.  For all those in priority measures, upper limit for event gatherings will also be limited to a maximum of 5,000 or half of the venue's capacity, whichever is the smallest number of attendees. Loud events may only operate at 50% venue capacity, all other events may operate at 100% venue capacity.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220307055524/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220304021624/http://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220303/k10013511781000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220307063439/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1021127.html

On March 21 2022, priority measures in all prefectures have been lifted.    Events continue to be permitted and infection precautions are encouraged. There remains a maximum of 5000 people with 100% venue capacity for events with no loud noises, and a maximum of 5000 people with 50% venue capacity for events with loud noises.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220322012508/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220322020303/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220317/k10013537981000.html

No change to previous policy. The government continues to encourage people to avoid dense crowds and situations of high risk for infection, to refrain for unnecessary movement to areas with high infection rates. Telework is also highly encouraged.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220225195546/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/

No change to previous policy. The government continues to encourage people to avoid dense crowds and situations of high risk for infection, to refrain for unnecessary movement to areas with high infection rates. Telework is also encouraged.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220322012508/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/

The government continues to encourage residents to practice precautions moving between prefectures, particularly to and from areas of high infection rates and particularly for those unvaccinated.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220225195546/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/

The government continues to encourage residents to practice precautions moving between prefectures, particularly to and from areas of high infection rates and particularly for those unvaccinated.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220322012508/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/

The government is looking to gradually open up borders and have announced that by the beginning of March, Japan will be permitting 5,000 individuals a day to enter the country, up from 3,500. However, leisure and non-Visa travel from all countries continues to be restricted for most travellers.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220220030103/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220216/k10013486121000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220220030144/https://jp.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220220030257/https://www.mofa.go.jp/mofaj/ca/fna/page4_005130.html

On February 25 2022, online application for entry is open in advance of the gradual relaxation of border measures beginning March 1 2022.  On March 1st, Japan will increase the maximum number of foreigners entering the country from the current 3,500 to 5,000 and gradually increase more entry.  Entry without an approved VISA sponsored by a Japanese workplace or school continues to be restricted.    https://web.archive.org/web/2/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220225/k10013501761000.html

On March 1st, Japan begins increasing the maximum number of foreigners entering the country from the current 3,500 to 5,000. Entry without an approved VISA sponsored by a workplace or a school continues to be restricted. Travel for leisure and tourism continues to be restricted.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220307060747/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220301/k10013506061000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220303111053/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220225/k10013501761000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220307065250/https://jp.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

The government is looking to expedite the entry for authorized foreigners into Japan (i.e. those with valid travel VISAs for business or education purposes). Japan is looking to permit 150,000 foreign students to enter the country by the end of May 2022.  On March 14 2022, Japan announced they will raise their daily upper limit of inbound travellers from 5,000 people to 7,000 people.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220311214604/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220309/k10013521921000.html

On March 14 2022, Japan announced they will raise their daily upper limit of inbound travellers from 5,000 people to 7,000 people.  However, travel remains restricted to Visa holders and travel for tourism purposes continue not to be permitted entry.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220311214604/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220309/k10013521921000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220322020344/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220316/k10013534891000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220322021949/https://jp.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

No change to previous policy. New unemployment subsidy application deadlines for January-March 2022 have been set for June 30, 2022 (support document partially revised as of Jan 28 2022).  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide financial support in the forms of: employment subsidies to encourage business owners to maintain employees, leave of absence due to COVID-19 infection, living expenses for leave of absence or the unemployed, and special support for low-income child-rearing households for a maximum of 50,000 yen per child. Employment subsidies have a maximum of 15,000 yen per day per person.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220211190020/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220211190012/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdf

No change to previous policy. New unemployment subsidy application deadlines and support policy documents have been updated as of Mar 1 2022.  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide financial support in the forms of: employment subsidies to encourage business owners to maintain employees, leave of absence due to COVID-19 infection, living expenses for leave of absence or the unemployed, and special support for low-income child-rearing households for a maximum of 50,000 yen per child. Employment subsidies have a maximum of 15,000 yen per day per person.  For note, "Elementary School Leave Subsidy" is a system to support parents who have to take a break from work when the school or nursery school where their children attend is closed or closed due to the influence of COVID. Deadline have been extended until the end of June.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220307055840/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220307063810/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20220307060512/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220226/k10013502281000.html

No change to previous policy. New debt relief subsidy application deadlines for January-March 2022 have been set for June 30, 2022 (support document partially revised as of Jan 28 2022).  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide debt relief: loans for small-lot emergency funds and comprehensive unemployment funds are provided at interest-free and payments may be deferred up to one year. Housing security loans are available for those at risk of losing housing: rent payments may be deferred up to 9-months with evidence of employment search. Property tax exemption may be available for applicants facing declining income or unemployment due to the pandemic. For single-parent households, family housing support loan of upto 40,000 yen for 12 months is available interest-free for a one-time redemption if the parent continues to work for a year. Interviews for single-parent households will be conducted to understand their living conditions, motivation for employment, efforts to acquire qualifications, etc. A policy is also in place for the deferment for payments of national taxes.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220211190020/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220211190012/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdf

No change to previous policy. New debt relief subsidy application deadlines and support policy documents have been updated as of Mar 1 2022.  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide debt relief: loans for small-lot emergency funds and comprehensive unemployment funds are provided at interest-free and payments may be deferred up to one year. Housing security loans are available for those at risk of losing housing: rent payments may be deferred up to 9-months with evidence of employment search. Property tax exemption may be available for applicants facing declining income or unemployment due to the pandemic. For single-parent households, family housing support loan of upto 40,000 yen for 12 months is available interest-free for a one-time redemption if the parent continues to work for a year. Interviews for single-parent households will be conducted to understand their living conditions, motivation for employment, efforts to acquire qualifications, etc. A policy is also in place for the deferment for payments of national taxes.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220307055840/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220307063810/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdf

Comprehensive public information about COVID-19 continues to be disseminated by the government.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220225200557/https://corona.go.jp/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220225200630/https://corona.go.jp/dashboard/

No change to previous policy. In Yokohama, rapid antigen test kits are also being sent out to relieve strain on PCR testing due to staff shortages at hospitals and health lab facilities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220225201303/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220222/k10013496881000.html

Ehime prefecture has been conducting free PCR and antigen tests across 80 pharmacies and clinics for asymptomatic people beginning January, expected to run until the end of March. However, due to supply issues, testing kits are becoming scarce and thus asymptomatic testing will be suspended beginning week of March 7.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220307061753/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220304/k10013513511000.html

By the end of February 2022, Japanese government is pushing to complete third dose vaccinations for elderly population in long-term care homes. The government also announces that the next priority group to become eligible for third doses in late February are education workers. Japan continues to administer third doses to residents, about 1.1 million administered per day.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220220025340/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220215/k10013484591000.html (education workers)  https://web.archive.org/web/20220220025713/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220218/k10013491621000.html (LTC homes)  https://web.archive.org/web/20220220025733/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220215/k10013484741000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220220025720/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220216/k10013487201000.html

On February 21 2022, vaccination begin for children ages 5-11 across Japan for the first time. All vaccinations are subsidized by the government. Tokyo also begins opening more vaccination clinics in schools and Shinjuku to encourage young people to get vaccinated.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220225202205/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220221/k10013494211000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220225202220/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220222/k10013496321000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220225095245/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220225/k10013501011000.html

On February 28, mass vaccination for third doses begin being administered to employees of small to medium-sized businesses in Tokyo.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220310014312/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220228/k10013505751000.html

Vaccinations for children 5-11 continue to be administered.  Third doses continue for the elderly and employees of small to medium size businesses. The government reports that about 70% of the elderly population in Japan had received their third doses by the end of February 2022.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220311033316/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220308/k10013519761000.html

Third dose vaccination begins in Tokyo's mass vaccination site on January 31 2022. In Osaka, third doses will be administered at the Osaka mass vaccination site beginning February 7. In Yokohama City, the municipal with the largest elderly population residing in the country, third dose vaccinations have already been underway and continues to be administered.    Schedule for third doses are as follows:  Feburary: 1.83 million medical workers and 11.6 million elderly people, 730,000 under 64 years old will be eligible.  March: 890,000 medical workers, 16.24 million elderly people, 64 years old or younger In addition to 4.35 million people, 1.68 million people who are "work-related inoculations" conducted at companies and universities are also eligible.  April: 3.13 million elderly people, 11.94 million people under 64 years old, 5 million occupational inoculations will be eligible.  May: 580,000 elderly people, 14.62 million people under 64 years old, 1.55 million occupational inoculations will be eligible.  June: 350,000 elderly people, 12.73 million under 64 years old, and 2.48 million occupational inoculations will be eligible and continue until September 2022.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211203031729/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211201/k10013369451000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220207235727/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220131/k10013457771000.html (Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20220207235340/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220130/k10013457321000.html (Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20220207235402/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220131/k10013458301000.html (Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20220207235928/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220207/k10013470791000.html (Osaka)  https://web.archive.org/web/20220207235927/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220207/k10013471291000.html (Yokohama)

Third dose mass vaccination begins in Tokyo, starting with the elderly population. Yokohama City, who has already been administered third doses, continue to inoculate their population. Osaka will begin mass vaccination for third doses (beginning with the elderly) on February 7.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220207235727/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220131/k10013457771000.html (Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20220207235340/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220130/k10013457321000.html (Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20220207235402/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220131/k10013458301000.html (Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20220207235928/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220207/k10013470791000.html (Osaka)  https://web.archive.org/web/20220207235927/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220207/k10013471291000.html (Yokohama)

From FB page of Office of Te Beretitenti (date of post was 19/02/22 but post refers to policy measures introduced on 18/02/22)    Targeted measure: "8. School closure until the end of this month."    "Government has decided to further extend the lockdown period on the islands of North Tarawa, Maiana, Abaiang, Marakei and Abemama for another two more weeks or may be longer should the need arise and with different conditions due to the slow in spread of the diseases on these islands, effective from Friday 18th of February 2022. The islands of Aranuka and Makin who have just affected with the spread of COVID-19 will also be included among these islands.    Subsequent to the decision pertaining to this extension, there are also new decisions put in place in addition to the current measures under the Alert Level 3. These new measures which will only apply on North Tarawa, Maiana, Abaiang, Marakei and Abemama, including  Aranuka and Makin are as follows:  1. Curfew hours from 6pm to 6am everyday.   2. All Government Offices and SOES will be closed and work remotely from home, except for essential and emergency services which also follow the Ministry of Health and Medical Services (MHMS) guidelines:  ? Island Council Office  ? Hospital services  ? Police services  ? Kiribati Oil Company and gas stations  ? Wholesalers and retailers selling food  ? Telecommunication service providers  ? Kiribati Red Cross Society  ? Kiribati Family Health Association  3. And other essential that the Government and the Island Council deems necessary during the curfew. These additional services require prior approval of the Island Council Office.  4. All essential service providers (food wholesale and retail) from the private sector will remain open to the public from 6am to 6pm.  5. People MUST stay at home â may only leave their homes for essential work, or to access emergency services but must observe compulsory face mask, social distancing of 2 meters, not spitting and nose blowing in public places and other guidelines from the Ministry of Health and Medical Services (MHMS).  6. Access to shops for food shopping and other essential services will be zoned to limit the movement of people within their neighborhoods or villages from 6am to 6pm.  7. Public transportation services may operate but will also observe compulsory face mask, open windows, no spitting and nose blowing, and other MHMS guidelines and passengers must not share seats nor stand.  8. School closure until the end of this month.  9. All kava bars, liquor bars, and night clubs will be closed  10. Social gatherings (including Churches) up to 20 people are allowed to gather in outdoor setting. With appropriate distance, masks and good ventilation.  11. Access to hospital services will be conducted accordingly to the Ministry of Health and Medical Services guidelines as earlier announced.  12. Delivery of cargoes , fuels and medical supplies by vessels or air services will continue to outer island with no passengers allowed. Only those stranded in the outer islands are allowed to return to Tarawa provided they meet health travel requirements.  13. No travels between the outer islands are allowed.  14. All police officers and other responsible Government officers are hereby ordered to ensure that this Order and future directions issued out of this Order and Public Health (Infectious Disease) Regulation and the Disaster Risk Management and Climate Change Act are complied with by the public.   15. Urgent direction(s) other than those listed here, if there is a need, may be issued later to the police and other officers of the Government for execution in relation to certain areas or groups of people or activities etc where it deemed necessary to achieve the purposes of this Order and the Public Health (Infectious Disease) Regulation and the Disaster Risk Management and Climate Change Act in relation to COVID-19.  16. Any person who contravenes any conditions of this Order commits an offence and will be liable to be arrested by the police or imprisonment. For clarification purposes, any breach of all the provisions of the Public Health (Infectious Disease) Regulation is an offence.  17. In case of any inconsistencies between this version and the Kiribati version, the Kiribati version shall prevail.  18. This Order repeals any previous Order and is effective on 18th February 2022 at 6 am until 4th March 2022 at 6am.  19. The non-affected islands with COVID-19 will continue their operations as usual.    Any person who contravenes any conditions of this Order commits an offence and will be liable to be arrested by the police or imprisonment. For clarification purposes, any breach of all the provisions of the Public Health (Infectious Disease) Regulation is an offence.   In case of any inconsistencies between this version and the Kiribati version, the Kiribati version shall prevail.    The public is advised to continue to strictly follow the Ministry of Health and Medical Services Standard Operational Procedures, comply with the curfew order, and to visit clinics for test if receiving symptoms to safeguard themselves and their families from this pandemic.    http://archive.today/7Q8G0

From Office of Te Beretitenti (FB page), announcing extension of policy measures from 4th-18th March  "Government has decided that similar measures applied in the curfew orders for i) South Tarawa, Betio, Buota and Butaritari together with ii) Tarawaieta, Maiana, Abaiang, Marakei, Abemama, Aranuka and Makin within the last two weeks are to remain in place and extended from Friday 4th to Friday 18th of March 2022 including new measures.     Curfew order for South Tarawa, Betio, Buota and Butaritari remains the same. Measures implemented within the last two weeks such as curfew hours between 7pm until 6am the next day, social gatherings involving not more than 20 people are allowed; schools will continue on Radio Kiribati and internet, kava and liquor bars will remain closed to name a few, including mandatory mask wearing. "    http://archive.today/JgUU6

Travel is currently permitted throughout Laos in areas with no community transmission or in provinces with community transmission if the traveler has evidence of two doses of COVID-19 vaccination a month or more prior to travel. Travel is prohibited in localized areas (red zones) where community transmission of COVID-19 is present.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220315180130/https://la.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

In Vientiane Capital region and any province with community spread, Traffic curfew between 11:30 pm to 5 am except for ambulances, fire trucks, rescue teams, those authorized by the task force, on-duty officials, and vehicles transporting goods, food, and medical supplies. During these hours, people must stay at home.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220315180229/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/laos/coronavirus  https://web.archive.org/web/20220315180130/https://la.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Travel is currently permitted throughout Laos in areas with no community transmission or in provinces with community transmission if the traveler has evidence of two doses of COVID-19 vaccination a month or more prior to travel. Travel is prohibited in localized areas (red zones) where community transmission of COVID-19 is present.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220315180130/https://la.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

While the Government of Laos is not issuing tourist visas at this time, those who currently hold or are issued valid multiple entry long-term visas (i.e. work or diplomatic visa) may return to Laos, though permission to enter is also subject to additional requirements. To avoid a second 14-day quarantine, foreign citizens who intend to travel to another province after arriving in Vientiane must submit the following documents to relevant officials: a travel itinerary, evidence of a 14-day quarantine, and authorization from the National Taskforce for COVID-19 Prevention and Control. If these documents are not submitted, foreign citizens should expect to do a 14-day quarantine in Vientiane and a 14-day quarantine at another province â their final destination. All travelers are screened for COVID-19 at the airport on arrival and before departing Laos.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220315180130/https://la.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

VIENTIANE, Feb. 21 (Xinhua) -- The Lao government has vowed to expedite a nationwide vaccination program for children aged 6 and over against COVID-19, starting on Monday.  The program is part of the government's efforts to ensure that people of all ethnic groups are immunized against COVID-19 and are protected against the Omicron variant in particular, as the variant is much more transmissible than the Delta variant, the local daily Vientiane Times reported on Monday.  Vaccinations will take place in the provinces of Huaphan, Xieng Khuang, Oudomxay, Savannakhet and Xaysomboun from Feb. 21 to March 4, according to a notice issued by the Prime Minister's Office.  In other provinces and the Lao capital Vientiane, vaccination rollout is scheduled for March 4 to 19. However, provinces that are ready can start inoculating children on Feb. 21.    https://archive.ph/xoQ4u

Land rental: Exemption of land rental under MOP$100.00.  Property tax: Standard deduction of MOP$3,500.00 on property tax. If the taxpayer is two or more natural persons (individuals), its property tax can be similarly deducted the aforementioned amount if and only if one of them is permanent resident of Macao SAR. If the taxpayer is a legal person, individual commercial entrepreneur or non-resident of Macao SAR, it is not eligible for such deduction.     Salaries tax: 30% exemption on salaries tax and the exemption allowance for its assessment in 2022 is MOP$144,000.00. In case of the following situation: employer should withhold tax from causal worker whose daily salary is over MOP$640.00 or employee whose monthly salary is over MOP$16,000.00. Please refer to the Simulation Calculation disposal in website of FSB. In addition, exemption allowance for part-time and employee who are aged 65 or above or with permanent disability level of or above 60%, is adjusted to MOP$198,000.00.    https://archive.ph/4NMvV

Two states are in Phase 3, Sarawak and Kelantan. Others are in Phase 4. For Phase 3 states, "All educational institutions are reopened; institutions under the Ministry of Education will open by stages, subject to risk assessments and the Ministry of Education. Face-to-face learning activities are allowed; face-to-face learning activities by higher education institutions are subject to 70% student capacity limits and SOP". For Phase 4 states, "All educational institutions are reopened, subject to current risk assessment".    Vaccination is mandatory for university students to go to campus, but not for other levels.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220320043129/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/johor/dashboard-en.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220222065648/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/johor/index-en.html

Two states are in Phase 3, Sarawak and Kelantan. Others are in Phase 4. For Phase 3 states, "Public sector limited to 80% employee attendance at offices subject to the Chief Secretary to the Governmentâs directive. Private sector limited to 80% employee attendance capacity, for business sectors allowed to operate. Agricultural and commodities sector may operate at full capacity". Some entertainment business is still closed. "Live performances/events are not allowed".    There is no mention of vaccine mandate policy.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220320043129/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/johor/dashboard-en.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220222065648/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/johor/index-en.html

Two states are in Phase 3, Sarawak and Kelantan. Others are in Phase 4. For Phase 3 states, "Live performances/events are not allowed. Only streaming of recordings and live streaming are allowed. Fully Vaccinated Individuals: Allowed to go to live performances/events, cinemas, art exhibitions, museums, indoor buskings and hotel lounges." For fully vaccinated individuals, religious gatherings are allowed subject to capacity limits.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220320043129/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/johor/dashboard-en.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220222065648/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/johor/index-en.html

Two states are in Phase 3, Sarawak and Kelantan. Others are in Phase 4. For Phase 3 states, "All social activities and visitations are not allowed". For Phase 4 States, "All social activities and visitations are allowed, limited to 50% space capacity and physical distancing".    https://web.archive.org/web/20220320043129/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/johor/dashboard-en.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220222065648/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/johor/index-en.html

Two states are in Phase 3, Sarawak and Kelantan. Others are in Phase 4. For all states, vehicles may carry passengers at full capacity.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220320043129/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/johor/dashboard-en.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220222065648/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/johor/index-en.html

No recommendations or requirements.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220320043129/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/johor/dashboard-en.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220222065648/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/johor/index-en.html

Two states are in Phase 3, Sarawak and Kelantan. Others are in Phase 4. For Phase 3 states, "Travelling between districts of the same state are allowed". For Phase 4 states, "Inter-state travel between phase 4 states is allowed".    Fully Vaccinated Individuals:  Travelling to districts / states / country and tourism bubble areas is allowed    https://web.archive.org/web/20220320043129/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/johor/dashboard-en.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220222065648/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/johor/index-en.html

Fully vaccinated individuals are permitted to enter Langkawi Island as a tourist under the international tourism bubble.     For fully vaccinated individuals, quarantine for 7 days on arrival in Malaysia, reduced to 5 days if one has received a vaccine booster. Citizens and non-citizens who have a residence in Malaysia and arrived from abroad, may have their compulsory quarantine at home.    Non-fully vaccinated individuals must quarantine in a designated quarantine centre for 10 days.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220320043129/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/johor/dashboard-en.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220222065648/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/johor/index-en.html

PSU is a financial assistance paid to the employer of each enterprise for each local employee.  It is targeted towards employers operating in the tourism sector, who experienced a decrease in income of at least 30% of total sales or income. It is a wage subsidy of RM600 (USD $143) per month for each employee, for 3 months. It is limited to 500 employees per claim.    https://archive.vn/QZHmW

Bank Negara Malaysia (Central Bank of Malaysia) provides loan repayment assistance:  Moratorium for 6 months.  No supporting documentation required.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211226111954/https://www.bnm.gov.my/RA
The government has a dedicated website for COVID-19.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220129102417/https://covid--19-moh-gov-my.translate.goog/?_x_tr_sl=ms&_x_tr_tl=en&_x_tr_hl=en&_x_tr_pto=nui%2Csc

Self-administered Testing kits are now also available to be ordered from the government website.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211018160735/https://covid--19-moh-gov-my.translate.goog/garis-panduan/gp-umum-covid19/kit-ujian-kendiri-covid19-self-test-kit?_x_tr_sl=ms&_x_tr_tl=en&_x_tr_hl=en&_x_tr_pto=nui%2Csc

The use of the MySejethera app is not mandated but generally used across Malaysia for many functions including booking vaccinations and tracking social movements.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211226113805/https://mysejahtera.malaysia.gov.my/intro_en/
Facial coverings are required in Malaysia.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220222065648/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/johor/index-en.html

Vaccinations are freely available and fully funded by the government for all citizens and foreign residents. Walk-in booster vaccinations for adults 18 years and above opened nationwide on January 29, 2022.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220222083033/https://my.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
No specific information on elderly.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220222065648/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/johor/index-en.html

Vaccinations are freely available and fully funded by the government for all citizens and foreign residents. Walk-in booster vaccinations for adults 18 years and above opened nationwide on January 29, 2022.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220222083033/https://my.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

Malaysia started COVID-19 vaccination programme for children aged five to 11 on Feb 3, 2022.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220222071136/https://www.straitstimes.com/asia/se-asia/malaysia-starts-vaccinating-5-to-11-year-old-kids-amid-worries-over-school-clusters
Both citizens and foreigners receive free vaccination.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220222083033/https://my.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

It is mandatory for all federal government employees to be vaccinated.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220129103725/https://www.reuters.com/world/asia-pacific/malaysia-makes-covid-19-vaccinations-compulsory-government-employees-2021-09-30/

21/3/22  Schools open with mask wearing and social distancing in place.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220321100827/https://temahau.govt.nz/covid-19/advice-early-learning-services/covid-19-protection-framework-early-learning-services/red

21/3/22  Close prpoximity businesses are only open to people with a My Vaccine Pass    If you have a My Vaccine Pass, you can visit a close-proximity business, such as a hairdresser.  You must wear a face mask when you visit a close-proximity business.  Workers working at close-proximity businesses must wear a face mask.  Scan the QR code or keep a record of where you go.  If you are unwell, are isolating or waiting for the results of a COVID-19 test, call and reschedule your appointment.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220321103028/https://covid19.govt.nz/traffic-lights/life-at-red/shopping-and-services-at-red/close-proximity-businesses-at-red/

Events are limited to 100 people if everyone has a My Vaccine Pass.  Events cannot go ahead if My Vaccine Pass requirements are not followed.  Compulsory Face masks should be worn at an event.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220215072048/https://covid19.govt.nz/traffic-lights/life-at-red/events-and-public-facilities-at-red/events-at-red/

21/3/22  Gatherings can go ahead.  Gatherings are limited to 100 people if everyone has a My Vaccine Pass.  Gatherings are limited to 25 people if My Vaccine Passes are not being used.  Children and babies are included in the gathering limits â but not people working at a gathering.  You do not need to wear a face mask at a gathering when your gathering is the only one using the defined space and other people cannot mix with your guests.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220312005342mp_/https://covid19.govt.nz/traffic-lights/life-at-red/gatherings-and-visits-at-red/

You can travel anywhere in New Zealand at all traffic light settings. There are no boundaries under the traffic lights.  You can travel for any reason.  Unless your transport provider requires it, you do not need a My Vaccine Pass or a negative COVID-19 test to travel.      https://web.archive.org/web/20220321113919/https://covid19.govt.nz/traffic-lights/life-at-red/travel-and-accommodation-at-red/travel-at-red/

Without My Vaccine Pass, there are restrictions.  You can travel anywhere in New Zealand for any reason, and see friends and whanau.   With My Vaccine Pass, most parts of life continue as usual. You can visit cafes and bars, attend gatherings and events, and go to the hairdresser and gym.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220321115624/https://covid19.govt.nz/traffic-lights/life-at-red/

If you arrive on or after Wednesday 2 March, 11.59 pm, you can enter without needing to isolate.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220321123159/https://www.immigration.govt.nz/about-us/covid-19/border-closures-and-exceptions/border-entry-requirements

Step 2 â from Friday 4 March, 11.59 pm  The border opened to New Zealanders and other eligible travellers coming from anywhere in the world. You do not need to self-isolate when you arrive.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220321123159/https://www.immigration.govt.nz/about-us/covid-19/border-closures-and-exceptions/border-entry-requirements

21/3/22  Travellers from countries other than Australia banned    Fully vaccinated eligible travellers will no longer self-isolate  Advice from the Strategic COVID-19 Public Health Advisory Group and the Director General of Health is that it is now appropriate to drop the requirement for self-isolation for fully vaccinated travellers after they arrive in New Zealand.    Cabinet has agreed to lift all self-isolation requirements for vaccinated travellers entering New Zealand from 11:59pm on Wednesday 2 March 2022. That means New Zealand citizens and other eligible travellers entering the country will be able to step off the plane and immediately connect with family and friends and enjoy all New Zealand has to offer.    Caution has served us well during the past 2 years and as we continue to move through the Omicron outbreak and peak, we will continue to remove restrictions when advised it is safe to do so â as we always said we would.    Now that we are 2 years into the COVID-19 pandemic, the risk has shifted from our border to our community. As the pandemic evolves, we are too. Getting tested is now quicker and easier, requirements for isolation have been simplified to those who share a household, and care in the community is focused towards those most in need of support.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220215081617/https://covid19.govt.nz/news-and-data/latest-news/new-zealand-border-to-reopen-in-stages-from-27-february/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220321101923/https://covid19.govt.nz/news-and-data/latest-news/self-isolation-requirements-removed-step-2-brought-forward/
