21/3/22  Mandatory vaccinations for workers  These sectors and business types are where COVID-19 vaccinations are mandatory.  Border and managed isolation and quarantine workers  Education sector   Health and disability sector  Prison workers  NZ Police  NZ Defence Force  Fire and Emergency New Zealand  Workers covered by the My Vaccine Pass mandate. This applies to food and drink services (excluding businesses that operate solely as takeaways), events, close-proximity businesses and indoor exercise facilities like gyms. The mandate also applies to workers on-site at tertiary education premises when Red settings are in place.  https://archive.fo/8TUmR  https://web.archive.org/web/20220227122622/https://www.health.govt.nz/covid-19-novel-coronavirus/covid-19-response-planning/covid-19-mandatory-vaccinations

All schools reopened on Jan 31 after Dec break. All schools, educational institutions, markets, and shopping centers are exempted from gathering numbers but must comply with Niupela Pasin.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220312153847/https://edu.pngfacts.com/education-news/png-education-minister-commends-teachers-for-successful-completion-of-national-examinations  https://web.archive.org/web/20220312154156/https://edu.pngfacts.com/education-news/over-58000-teachers-resume-duties-today  https://web.archive.org/web/20220312161804/https://covid19.info.gov.pg/files/National%20Pandemic%20Measures/Pandemic%20Measures%2016022022/Measure%203-Domestic%20Measures-16.02.22.pdf

The following Measures apply to all Provinces:  a. Venues or parts of venues that operate as a restaurant or for food consumption on-premises may operate subject to:  1. all persons on entry and exit from venues must wash their hands with soap or hand sanitizer, and follow all other hygiene standards as issued by the Controller.  b. Venues or parts of venues that provide gambling activities and services may open if they ensure strict adherence to the COVID-19 safety guidelines issued by the Controller in relation to operating a gambling activity and service.  c. No licensed premises shall sell takeaway alcohol on Friday, Saturday, or Sunday, except restaurants that may continue to serve alcohol as regulated by their liquor license.  All schools, educational institutions, markets, and shopping centers are exempted from gathering numbers but must comply with Niupela Pasin.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220312161804/https://covid19.info.gov.pg/files/National%20Pandemic%20Measures/Pandemic%20Measures%2016022022/Measure%203-Domestic%20Measures-16.02.22.pdf

All religious activities are exempted from gathering numbers and may continue to operate but must comply with Niupela Pasin. All political rallies,  events, and gatherings only connected to the  National  Election  2022 are exempted from gathering numbers but must comply with Niupela Pasin.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220312161804/https://covid19.info.gov.pg/files/National%20Pandemic%20Measures/Pandemic%20Measures%2016022022/Measure%203-Domestic%20Measures-16.02.22.pdf

Nationwide, religious, school, and political gatherings, as well as crowds at markets and shopping malls, are allowed to exceed 100 people from 16 Feb 2022, though the limitation remains for public gatherings.  Gatherings are still banned in high-risk regions.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220220234935/https:/crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/02/papua-new-guinea-officials-ease-covid-19-travel-restrictions-as-of-feb-16-some-domestic-measures-continuing-update-46

An immediate ban is placed on gatherings of over 100 people in Niupela Pasin.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220312161804/https://covid19.info.gov.pg/files/National%20Pandemic%20Measures/Pandemic%20Measures%2016022022/Measure%203-Domestic%20Measures-16.02.22.pdf

As of Feb 16, restrictions on public transport have been lifted.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220221000020/https:/postcourier.com.pg/covid-19-restrictions-no-longer-apply-on-public-transport/    https://web.archive.org/web/20220220234935/https:/crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/02/papua-new-guinea-officials-ease-covid-19-travel-restrictions-as-of-feb-16-some-domestic-measures-continuing-update-46
There is no curfew in place.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220312164141/https://pg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
There are no restrictions on intercity or interstate travel.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220312164141/https://pg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Papua New Guinea authorities have reopened borders to tourists as of Feb. 16. Officials have also lifted requirements for arrivals to have written permission from the National Pandemic Controller's Office to enter. All arrivals must be fully vaccinated, though Papua New Guinea citizens and travelers under 18 years old are exempted. Entrants must also provide a negative COVID-19 test obtained within 72 hours before departure and undergo a COVID-19 test upon arrival. Individuals who tested positive in the last three months must provide a medical certificate indicating the person is no longer infectious. Authorities are not enforcing mandatory quarantine for most arrivals; people who test positive when tested on arrival must quarantine for seven days.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220220234935/https:/crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/02/papua-new-guinea-officials-ease-covid-19-travel-restrictions-as-of-feb-16-some-domestic-measures-continuing-update-46    https://web.archive.org/web/20220221000020/https:/postcourier.com.pg/covid-19-restrictions-no-longer-apply-on-public-transport/

All travelers age 5 and over must present a negative COVID-19 PCR or Abbot Panbio Antigen Rapid Diagnostic test administered no earlier than 72 hours prior to departure from their original point of origin.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220312164141/https://pg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

PNG government announced a K5.6 billion economic stimulus package, including a K600 million credit line to support businesses and individuals, in coordination with the banks and financial institutions, and K500 million in support from superannuation savings to employees affected by the economic slowdown.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220312165647/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

The Bank of Papua New Guinea (BPNG) reduced the Kina Facility Rate (KFR) â the main policy rate - by 200 basis points to 3 percent from 5 percent and asked the commercial banks to reduce their respective Indicative Lending Rates. BPNG also reduced the Cash Reserve Requirement to 7 percent from 10 percent to provide additional liquidity to the commercial banks. All financial institutions agreed to provide relief of 3 months on loan repayments and interest payments to customers who have lost their jobs, on a case-by-case basis.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220312165647/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
There are Covid-19 awareness videos and posters updated online at the specialized Covid-19 website.    https://archive.ph/AnJ2Q
COVID-19 testing services and health care capacity in the country are limited only to symptomatic people.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220312164141/https://pg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
COVID-19 testing services and health care capacity including contact tracing in the country are limited.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220312164141/https://pg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

All people must wear masks in the entire country whenever going outside.  The following persons are exempted from these Measures:  a. Children under 12;  b. Persons with underlying medical conditions which inhibit their ability to wear a Mask or Face Covering, including persons with physical or mental illness or impairment, or disability  c. Persons who are unable to place or remove a Mask or Face Covering without assistance;  d. Persons undergoing dental treatment or other medical care to the extent that the procedure requires that no face covering may be worn;  e. Persons within an area of work designated for them and not for public access, and who can work in an environment whereby they are a minimum of 2 meters from any other person;  f. Persons participating in sporting activities;  g. When directed to remove the face covering to ascertain identity; and  h. During emergencies.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220312171122/https://covid19.info.gov.pg/files/National%20Pandemic%20Measures/Pandemic%20Measures%2016022022/Measure%209-Mandatory%20Mask%20Wearing-16.02.22.pdf

All persons 18 years of age or older are eligible for vaccination in Papua New Guinea. AstraZeneca, Johnson & Johnson, and Sinopharm are available in Papua New Guinea.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220312164141/https://pg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
Boosters are available for eligible individuals like elderly people.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220312164141/https://pg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
All persons 18 years of age or older are eligible for vaccination in Papua New Guinea.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220312164141/https://pg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
348, 938 people who are older than 18 years old are actively vaccinated.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220312172640/https://covid19.info.gov.pg/
Vaccines are fully funded by the government    https://web.archive.org/web/20220312172640/https://covid19.info.gov.pg/
There are no mandatory vaccine requirements    https://web.archive.org/web/20220312172640/https://covid19.info.gov.pg/

no coding changes for the period of 23-26 Feb 2022.  ____________________  ***Please refer to previous notes dated 21 Feb 2022:  no coding changes to the period of 12-22 February 2022.    Vaccine differentiated measures have not imposed in schools.  Covid safety measures are currently still enforced in educational institutions.  _________________________    Quote (1):  "Will Vaccination Differentiated Safe Management Measures (VDS) be introduced in schools and IHLs?  There are presently no plans to introduce VDS in our pre-schools, primary schools or SPED schools with primary/junior section. Our priority now is to ensure our children are well protected against COVID-19 as we begin vaccination for those aged five to 11 years.    Similarly, COVID-19 vaccination is not a requirement for physical attendance in our secondary schools, SPED schools with secondary/senior sections, junior colleges and Millennia Institute. Access to quality education remains MOEâs priority. However, where there are public health reasons to better protect our students participating in higher risk activities, additional measures would be put in place. For example, unvaccinated students are required to perform a self-administered Antigen Rapid Test (ART) prior to participating in higher-risk activities such as singing and playing wind instruments. In addition, under the ongoing MCCY-MOE Team Sports Pilot for schools and IHLs, only fully vaccinated students who have taken an on-site ART self-swab are allowed to participate in team sports in groups of up to 10.    From 1 February 2022, VDS will be expanded to include Institutes of Higher Learning (IHLs). For now, VDS will only apply to all visitors who enter the IHLs. (IHL staff are already subject to VDS via MOMâs Workforce Vaccination Measures.) All students will be exempted from VDS. This exemption is subject to review.    To facilitate the safe resumption of in-person activities for IHL students, all unvaccinated students will be required to complete a weekly self-administered Antigen Rapid Test (ART) regime to take part in higher risk activities on campus which require VDS, such as indoor unmasked activities or large-scale student events.    All staff in schools or IHLs are to adhere to the Workforce Vaccination Measures put in place by MOM."      "What are the arrangements for Institutes of Higher Learning (IHLs) for the resumption of term in 2022?  The Institutes of Higher Learning (IHLs) have increased the number of students allowed back on campus at any one time for face-to-face learning.    More student activities and large scale student events will resume in line with national guidelines on group sizes and event sizes."    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20220222054820/https://www.moe.gov.sg/faqs-covid-19-infection

Streamlining of Covid measures in-country to begin on March 15 after a postponement from Feb 25 due to the surges in cases.  ___________________________  Quote (1):  "From 15 March 2022, Safe Management Measures will be simplified to focus on the five most important and effective measures:  a. Group sizes;  b. Mask-wearing;  c. Workplace requirements;  d. Safe distancing; and  e. Capacity limits"    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20220312111932/https://www.gov.sg/article/revised-safe-management-measures    ---------------------------  Quote (2):  "SINGAPORE - Singapore will simplify its safe management measures from next Tuesday (March 15), as the Omicron wave has likely peaked and Covid-19 cases are falling.  The streamlining, which was earlier announced but deferred due to a surge in cases, will cover five areas: group sizes, mask wearing, workplace rules, safe distancing and capacity limits.  Should the pandemic situation change, these parameters will be tightened or relaxed across the board. Other restrictions - such as the blocking-off of public seating areas - will be lifted, given that they do not have a big impact on the virus' spread." Easing of safe distancing measures that was announce recently over the past week have not been postponed to a later stage due to surge in cases. [1]    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20220226043144/https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/implementation-of-changes-to-covid-19-safe-management-measures-to-be-postponed-due-to-surge-in-cases-moh  ____________________  ***Please refer to previous notes dated 21 Feb 2022:    No Coding changes for the period of 12-22 February 2022.  _____________________________________  ***Please refer to notes dated 28 January 2022:    From 15 January 2022 onwards, a vaccine mandate for workers is implemented in order to be able to return to work places. Negative tests are no longer accepted for those unvaccinated.  A grace period for partially vaccinated individuals is in place until 31 January 2022.    50% of employees are now allowed back to the workplaces at any given point in time; although, they must adhere to the vaccine mandate as afore mentioned.  ____________    Quote (1):  "Phase 2 (15 January 2022 onwards): Only employees who are fully vaccinated, certified to be medically ineligible or have recovered from COVID-19 within 180 days, can return to the workplace. The concession for unvaccinated employees to perform PET in lieu of being fully vaccinated will be removed, i.e. such employees will not be allowed to return to the workplace even if they did PET with a negative result. Partially vaccinated7 employees will still be allowed at workplaces with a negative PET result up to 31 January 2022 after which they must be fully vaccinated."    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20220128135348/https://www.mom.gov.sg/covid-19/advisory-on-covid-19-vaccination-in-employment-settings  ___________    Quote (2):  "The following measures are put in place to slow the rate of transmission and minimise strain on our healthcare capacity.  From 1 January 2022, more employees3 are allowed to return to the workplace.  Up to 50% of employees who are able to work from home can be at the workplace at any point in time. For example, a company with 100 employees who can work from home can have up to 50 of these employees at the workplace at any point in time."    Link (2): http://web.archive.org/web/20220103082447/https://www.mom.gov.sg/covid-19/requirements-for-safe-management-measures

Although there have been some adjustments to covid measures, there are still some specific restrictions depending on the type and capacity of the event.  ____________    Quote (1):    "Capacity Limits    From 4 March 2022, specific event size limits for events such as religious services, business events, media conferences, funerary memorial events, wedding receptions, and mask-on classes1, will be lifted. Zoning requirements will also be removed.    However, for large events and settings which pose more infection risks, capacity limits will be imposed as a precaution. These will include attractions, cruises, MICE and large work-related events, as well as large performing arts venues or sports stadiums. For other settings such as shopping malls and large standalone stores, the current density limit of 10sqm/pax roughly translates to 50% capacity too. For now, we will set the threshold at 1,000 pax."    Link (1):  http://web.archive.org/web/20220222054302/https://www.gov.sg/article/revised-safe-management-measures-from-25-february-2022

For now, we will set the threshold at 1,000 pax."    Link (1):  http://web.archive.org/web/20220222054302/https://www.gov.sg/article/revised-safe-management-measures-from-25-february-2022

Although there have been some adjustments to covid measures, there are still some specific restrictions depending on the type and capacity of the event.  ____________    Quote (1):    "Capacity Limits    From 4 March 2022, specific event size limits for events such as religious services, business events, media conferences, funerary memorial events, wedding receptions, and mask-on classes1, will be lifted. Zoning requirements will also be removed.    However, for large events and settings which pose more infection risks, capacity limits will be imposed as a precaution. These will include attractions, cruises, MICE and large work-related events, as well as large performing arts venues or sports stadiums. For other settings such as shopping malls and large standalone stores, the current density limit of 10sqm/pax roughly translates to 50% capacity too. For now, we will set the threshold at 1,000 pax."    Link (1):  http://web.archive.org/web/20220222054302/https://www.gov.sg/article/revised-safe-management-measures-from-25-february-2022

Ridership rates have been on the rise and more hopes that might return to pre-pandemic levels. not restrictions in services seen.  ____________________    Quote (1):  "SINGAPORE - Public transport ridership recovered in 2021 on the back of relaxed Covid-19 restrictions, but the numbers are still the second lowest since 2010.  Bus and train rides averaged 5.259 million a day in 2021 - 4.3 per cent higher than in 2020, based on figures released by the Land Transport Authority on Monday (Feb 21)."    "More people are expected to return to taking public transport as the economy reopens further this year.  Last month, bus and rail rides averaged 5.785 million a day - a 10 per cent jump from the 2021 average.  But observers reckon that it would take some time to go back to the all-time ridership high of 7.691 million seen before the Covid-19 pandemic in 2019."    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20220222053312/https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/transport/bus-train-rides-rise-but-numbers-still-far-from-pre-covid-19-levels

We had earlier simplified our country/region classification and border measures on 22 February 2022 to pave the way for more Vaccinated Travel. Over the past weeks, imported infection numbers have stayed very low â around 1% of total daily infections â because many countries have already passed the peak of their Omicron infection waves.  28.          Given the above, we will now further rationalise our travel protocols by switching to an unsupervised self-swab Antigen Rapid Test (ART) within 24 hours of entry for General Category (Vaccinated Travel Lane (VTL)) and Category I travellers entering Singapore from 14 March 2022, 2359 hours. This will replace the previous requirement for a supervised self-swab ART. Travellers are required to report their unsupervised self-swab ART test result via sync.gov.sg3 before proceeding with their activities in Singapore. Border measures for travellers arriving from 14 March 2022, 2359h can be found at Annex C." no coding changes for the period of 23-26 Feb 2022.     Easing of safe distancing measures that was announce recently over the past week have not been postponed to a later stage due to surge in cases. [1]    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20220226043144/https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/implementation-of-changes-to-covid-19-safe-management-measures-to-be-postponed-due-to-surge-in-cases-moh  ------------------------------------  ***Please refer to previous notes dated 21 Feb 2022:    No coding changes for the period of 12-22 Feb 2022.  _______________________    Quote (1):  "About Combined Test Centres (CTCs)  Combined Test Centres (CTCs), previously known as Regional Screening Centres (RSCs), are set up around Singapore to carry out COVID-19 swab tests for target groups from the general community who are well or have been diagnosed with acute respiratory infection. CTCs provide both the self-paid Antigen Rapid Test (ART) and the COVID-19 Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) swab test.    Click here for the locations of CTCs.  About Quick Test Centres (QTCs)  Quick Test Centres (QTCs) provide self-paid ART, where the test will be self-administered and supervised by an approved COVID-19 test provider. The test will cost $15 (inclusive of GST), with payment to be made at the QTCs through cashless modes, such as Mastercard, NETS, PayNow and Visa. Individuals will need to bring along their photo identification for verification at the QTC.    Both the CTCs and QTCs are important as they support COVID-19 testing, which helps to keep our homes and communities safe, especially as we re-open and resume our activities.    Click here for the locations of QTCs CTCs."    "Expanded Venues for COVID-19 Testing for Symptomatic Individuals  Members of the public who are experiencing acute respiratory symptoms (e.g. fever, cough, flu or runny nose), and are unable to secure an appointment at any of the Swab and Send Home (SASH) clinics during the weekend and public holidays, may book an appointment here, at one of our Combined Testing Centres (CTCs) to get a government-funded ART and confirmatory PCR test.    For the locations of CTCs, click here.  Self-Paid Antigen Rapid Test for Pre-Event Testing  From 1 October 2021, individuals aged 3 years and above, who need a valid negative COVID-19 ART result for entry into venues that require a negative Pre-Event or Pre-Visit Test may book an appointment at any of the QTCs for a self-paid ART. Minors aged 3 to 12, must be accompanied by a caregiver, aged 21 years old and above. The caregiver may be required to help administer the test if the minor is unable to do so. The results, which are valid for 24 hours, may be used to meet requirements such as those for pre-event test or pre-visit test.     Individuals are required to book an appointment at any of the following testing venues, prior to the visit."    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20220222052846/https://www.moh.gov.sg/covid-19/quick-test-centres-%28qtcs%29

Masks help to reduce the expulsion and transmission of droplets, which is the predominant route of transmission of COVID-19. It is therefore important for you to wear a mask, so that you will not spread the infection to others if you are infected. No Coding changes for the period of 23-26 February 2022.  _____________________________________  ***Please refer to notes dated 22 January 2022:    From 15 January 2022 onwards, a vaccine mandate for workers is implemented in order to be able to return to work places. Negative tests are no longer accepted for those unvaccinated.    ***unable to tick "mandatory vaccination" as there is no suitable category for workers in general***  ____________    Quote (1):  "Phase 2 (15 January 2022 onwards): Only employees who are fully vaccinated, certified to be medically ineligible or have recovered from COVID-19 within 180 days, can return to the workplace. The concession for unvaccinated employees to perform PET in lieu of being fully vaccinated will be removed, i.e. such employees will not be allowed to return to the workplace even if they did PET with a negative result. Partially vaccinated7 employees will still be allowed at workplaces with a negative PET result up to 31 January 2022 after which they must be fully vaccinated."    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20220128135348/https://www.mom.gov.sg/covid-19/advisory-on-covid-19-vaccination-in-employment-settings

Localities remain grouped into orange, yellow, and blue zones in decreasing order of strictness. The government categorizes Bangkok and eight provinces as blue zones and 44 other provinces as the stricter orange zones. The following designations are in effect as of Feb. 23:    Blue: Bangkok; Chonburi, Kanchanaburi, Krabi, Nonthaburi, Pathum Thani, Phang Nga, and Phuket provinces    Yellow: Ang Thong, Bueng Kan, Chai Nat, Chaiyaphum, Kamphaeng Phet, Lampang, Lamphun, Loei, Nakhon Phanom, Nakhon Sawan, Narathiwat, Nong Bua Lam Phu, Nong Khai, Pattani, Phetchabun, Phichit, Phitsanulok, Phrae, Sakon Nakhon, Sing Buri, Sukhothai, Suphan Buri, Uthai Thani, Uttaradit, and Yala provinces    Orange: All other provinces    Gatherings are capped at 500 people in orange zones, and 1,000 people in yellow and blue zones.     https://archive.ph/p5He8

The governmentâs Center for COVID-19 Situation Administration said that starting from March 1, vaccinated international travelers will still have to undergo one reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) test after arriving. But they will no longer have to take another RT-PCR test on the fifth day of their arrival; instead they will able to do a rapid antigen test and report the result on a cellphone app.  Travelers who are not fully vaccinated must quarantine for 10 days and take three PCR tests.     https://archive.ph/Y8oFY

From March 1, 2022 onwards, Thailandâs Test & Go program allows fully vaccinated travelers from any country to enter Thailand after undergoing a self-funded RT-PCR test upon arrival and a one night stay in a government-approved hotel while awaiting test results. Travelers are also required to report the results of a self-administered rapid antigen self-test (ATK) on Day 5 via the MorChana Application. Travelers who are not fully vaccinated must quarantine for 10 days and take three PCR tests.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220315081910/https://www.tatnews.org/2022/02/thailand-reopening-exemption-from-quarantine-test-go/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220315082057/https://th.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

No policy update.  On 24th January, the 4th phase of âKhon La Khreungâ, the Thai governmentâs co-payment subsidy scheme was approved. Through this scheme, the government co-pays 50% of certain living costs (food, drink and other goods and services), capped at a maximum of 150 baht/day. Phase 3 had expired on 31st December 2021, and Phase 4 will come into effect from 1st February 2022 to 30th April 2022.    https://archive.ph/PvCJf

Hon. Huâakavameiliku confirmed that all businesses who have been approved to open will need to follow their compliance plans with effect from 28 Feb 2022. Liquor shops may also start opening daily from Monday to Saturday.  Bars and nightclubs and kava clubs must remain closed.    All licensed businesses and business activities shall be closed, except for the following â  (a) all licensed retail shops;  (b) any other licensed shop may operate subject to the approval of their COVID-19 plans by the Ministry of Health;  (c) any licensed restaurant and food related businesses may operate for takeaways only;  (d) any business with a Wholesale License or Retail Bottle Store License under the Intoxicating Liquor Act [Cap 12.07]; or  (e) gas stations.  All banking and other financial services referred to in paragraph 4(e) may operate subject to approval from the Ministry of Health. On 25 Aug 2021, Tonga legislative assembly approved the Public Health Amendment Bill 2021.  The Bill introduces a new 181A section intends to make vaccinations compulsory ONLY when prior declarations of public health emergency as well as an emergency notifiable condition in place. This includes the COVID-19 vaccine. From 16 Nov 2021 onwards, leisure and entertainment venues with escort services can open for business if they meet the epidemic prevention measures:  -From January 21, 2022, the public will go to "karaoke halls, dance halls, nightclubs, clubs, restaurants, bars, hotels (gallery), beauty salons (tourist haircuts, audio-visual grooming) and special coffee tea rooms, nightclubs, dance venues, In leisure and entertainment venues such as "Sannuan", the complete record of vaccination against COVID-19 should be presented before entry into activities and consumption.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220226054611/https://www.cdc.gov.tw/Category/ListContent/EmXemht4IT-IRAPrAnyG9A?uaid=FNjpFKjhjxvQ-imhFpOjeA    Public spaces and services  Taiwanâs Central Epidemic Command Center (CECC) has announced that starting from 1 March 2022, epidemic prevention measures across Taiwan will now be reviewed on a monthly basis. In line with the CECCâs general guidelines, the Taiwanese authorities have advised that further localised epidemic prevention measures may be introduced in certain cities or counties depending on the COVID-19 situation in each location.  For the month of March, the following measures are now in place:  From 21 January you must present your COVID-19 vaccination record to enter certain entertainment venues, including singing and dancing venues, discos, nightclubs, clubs, hostess bars, pubs, and beauty parlours (tourist parlours and audio-video parlours).    Venues will accept the paper-based âYellow Card,â vaccination record on the Taiwanese National Health Insurance app, and the Digital COVID-19 Certificate introduced in January 2022. If youâve been vaccinated in Taiwan you can download this Digital COVID-19 certificate from the Ministry for Health and Welfareâs website.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220322053102/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/taiwan/coronavirus

Public spaces and services  -Taiwanâs Central Epidemic Command Center (CECC) has announced that starting from 1 March 2022, epidemic prevention measures across Taiwan will now be reviewed on a monthly basis. In line with the CECCâs general guidelines, the Taiwanese authorities have advised that further localised epidemic prevention measures may be introduced in certain cities or counties depending on the COVID-19 situation in each location.  For the month of March, the following measures are now in place:  -Restaurants will permitted to offer dine-in services provided they adhere to Ministry of Health and Welfare regulations  -Public eating areas in supermarkets, shopping malls and convenience stores are permitted to open  https://web.archive.org/web/20220322053102/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/taiwan/coronavirus

The Central Epidemic Command Center stated today (24 Feb) that in order to maintain domestic epidemic prevention capacity, social and economic activities, and effectively control risks, after evaluating the domestic epidemic situation and the opening of international epidemic prevention measures, it announced that the implementation period of the Spring Festival quarantine project will be extended to this year. From March 6th (the scheduled arrival time of the flight to Taiwan), the relevant measures will maintain the special regulations; and from 0:00 on March 7, 2022 (the scheduled arrival time of the flight schedule), the number of days of entry home quarantine will be shortened to 10 The relevant measures are adjusted as follows:    1. The number of quarantine days and places:  (1) The number of days for home quarantine is 10 days, the day of entry is the 0th day, and the 7-day self-health management continues from the 11th day.  (2) The principle of one person and one household is the residence of oneâs own residence or the residence of relatives and friends. If the household cannot meet the quarantine conditions for one person and one household, it must stay in an anti-epidemic hotel and complete the 10-day quarantine.  (3) During the quarantine period, family members/companies who enter the country on the same day can live in their own home or the residence of relatives and friends, or live in one room at the anti-epidemic hotel according to the wishes of the public and according to the room type, but the single room is small, and it is recommended that no more than 2 people share the same room. Live as the principle.    2. Testing measures:  (1) PCR testing (2 times in total):  1. Conduct PCR testing according to the current measures at the time of entry (day 0).  2. Before the expiration of the quarantine period (the 10th day of quarantine), the PCR test will be carried out. If the test result is negative, the quarantine will be released after the expiration of the period, and the self-health management will continue for 7 days.  (2) Household rapid screening reagent detection (5 times in total):  1. On the 3rd, 5th, and 7th days of quarantine, and on the 3rd and 6th to 7th days of the self-health management period, perform a rapid screening each.  2. Household rapid screening reagents will be issued by personnel from various international ports upon entry.    -The command center emphasized that quarantine measures are one of the necessary lines of defense to control the epidemic. The public is requested to abide by the relevant matters during the quarantine period and jointly maintain the safety of the domestic community.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220322063951/https://www.cdc.gov.tw/Category/ListContent/EmXemht4IT-IRAPrAnyG9A?uaid=IdC18RauX3qPj9bo4RiY5g

Key measures of the covid relief package 4.0:  Accelerating relief for individuals: In addition to administering aid in accordance with last year's standards, a subsidy is available for families with students enrolled in elementary school and below, as well as disabled students in junior and senior high school and the first three years of five-year junior colleges. Living allowances are also going out to children, young people, the elderly and the disabled in low to middle-low income households. Excluding those above a certain income, agricultural and fisheries workers, the self-employed, and workers without fixed employers also receive living allowances.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220116055359/https://english.ey.gov.tw/News3/9E5540D592A5FECD/10e57174-8e16-4710-b4ac-9882bd8db7de    *No new policies found

Financial Relief    Three Ways to Help from Public Banks    1. Policy Lending Package: Support SMEs funding to operate business.  2. Loan Extension: Companies or individuals can apply to defer principal repayment or extend loan.  3. Credit card payment deferral: Individuals can apply to defer card payment without penalty and interest.    The measures of reducing interest rate from public banks  Residential Loan (For all loans): 0.25% lower since 2020/9/30  Consuming Loan (For all loans): 0.25% lower since 2020/9/30 (including credit card, unsecured loan, car loan)  https://web.archive.org/web/20220116055846/https://home.kpmg/xx/en/home/insights/2020/04/taiwan-government-and-institution-measures-in-response-to-covid.html    *No new policies found

Self-paid testing is available for both emergency and outpatient. e.g.     (1) To enter other countries for the compassionate reasons listed above.  (2) Job requirements.  (3) To study abroad.  (4) Foreign nationals, mainland Chinese, or Hong Kong and Macao residents who will depart from Taiwan.  (5) Family members of people traveling abroad for the reasons listed above. Public spaces and services  -Taiwanâs Central Epidemic Command Center (CECC) has announced that starting from 1 March 2022, epidemic prevention measures across Taiwan will now be reviewed on a monthly basis. In line with the CECCâs general guidelines, the Taiwanese authorities have advised that further localised epidemic prevention measures may be introduced in certain cities or counties depending on the COVID-19 situation in each location.  For the month of March, the following measures are now in place:  Contact tracing procedures must be completed when entering restaurants, shops and some public places    Any individual who receives a positive COVID-19 PCR test will be contacted by their local health bureau who will advise on their mandatory quarantine arrangements. Visit the Taiwan Centers for Disease Control website or contact their helpline on 1922 for further information.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220322053102/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/taiwan/coronavirus

Strengthen monitoring, adjust the home quarantine/isolation days to 10 days from now on, the date of rapid screening test for self-health management  -The Central Epidemic Command Center stated today (17th) that in view of the shortened incubation period of the Omicron variant strain, in order to strengthen surveillance, those entering Taiwan from 0:00 on March 7th, 2022 (the scheduled arrival time of the flight schedule) and the research and judgment are: For close contacts of confirmed cases, it was originally stipulated that after the expiration of the isolation/quarantine measures, self-health management should be carried out for 7 consecutive days, and the public-funded household rapid screening reagent test should be carried out on the 3rd day and the 6th-7th day. The aforementioned period will be adjusted from the same day It is performed once each on the second day and the fourth day of the self-health management period, and the test results are sent by two-way text messages, so that Lee can grasp the information in real time and implement necessary preventive measures.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220322063248/https://www.cdc.gov.tw/Category/ListContent/EmXemht4IT-IRAPrAnyG9A?uaid=t3Ss044INxOap4yqDTORdw

Public spaces and services  -Taiwanâs Central Epidemic Command Center (CECC) has announced that starting from 1 March 2022, epidemic prevention measures across Taiwan will now be reviewed on a monthly basis. In line with the CECCâs general guidelines, the Taiwanese authorities have advised that further localised epidemic prevention measures may be introduced in certain cities or counties depending on the COVID-19 situation in each location.  For the month of March, the following measures are now in place:  Facemasks should be worn at all times when outdoors. Exceptions are permitted when exercising, consuming food and beverages and when in certain open spaces e.g. forests, mountains and beaches  https://web.archive.org/web/20220322053102/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/taiwan/coronavirus

COVID-19 vaccine appointments for the first shot, second shot, or booster shot are widely available to people aged 12 or older.    Eligibility: individuals who registered on the System before 6 a.m. on December 13 and meet any of the following criteria:  1. The first dose of the BNT vaccine: people aged 12 or older (born on December 16, 2009, or earlier).  2. The second dose of the BNT vaccine: people aged 18 or older (born on December 31, 2003, or earlier) who received their first dose of BNT before November 18 (inclusive).  3. Mixing of AZ with a second dose of the BNT vaccine: people aged 18 or older (born on December 16, 2003, or earlier) who received their first dose of AZ before October 21 (inclusive).    https://web.archive.org/web/20220116062114/https://www.cdc.gov.tw/En/Bulletin/Detail/kaT7wZ1ubFZzyHlWUQsENg?typeid=158  https://web.archive.org/web/20220226060301/https://www.cdc.gov.tw/Category/ListContent/EmXemht4IT-IRAPrAnyG9A?uaid=Z0Az4TD0aBC1AsNJBlqSlA    Remarks:  The Central Epidemic Epidemic Command Center stated today (1) that in response to the domestic epidemic situation, the COVID-19 public-funded vaccine platform is open every Wednesday to Friday for people over the age of 18 to make an appointment for supplementary vaccination. The appointment time for this opening is March. From March 2 to March 4, the public has been provided to make an appointment for vaccination at contract medical institutions arranged or designated by the local government health bureau, or at the on-demand vaccination station for vaccination.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220322065005/https://www.cdc.gov.tw/Category/ListContent/EmXemht4IT-IRAPrAnyG9A?uaid=XySGMyEXOW1ijGj3cIYPWA

*Current is Phase 27    The command center pointed out that in order to provide the public with multiple options for vaccine appointment channels and to accelerate the improvement of public immunity protection, the COVID-19 public vaccine appointment platform (https://1922.gov.tw/, hereinafter referred to as the appointment platform) continues on every Wednesday. From 10:00 a.m. to 12:00 p.m. every Friday, public appointments are available, and vaccinations will start next week (Monday to Sunday); this time (Phase 27) provides "completely vaccinated two doses of COVID-19 vaccine for 12 weeks and 18 "People over the age of 3", who have made an appointment for vaccination supplements, those who have reached the vaccination interval and have not been vaccinated, please make an appointment as soon as possible. In addition, people who have completed appointments at contracted medical institutions arranged or designated by local government health bureaus are requested to still go for vaccinations according to the original appointment time period, and there is no need to make repeated appointments on the appointment platform.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220322065246/https://www.cdc.gov.tw/Category/ListContent/EmXemht4IT-IRAPrAnyG9A?uaid=5rXUgH4VCtOZbyC813Nx_g

On 04 March 2022, an active COVID-19 case was confirmed at Vila Central Hospital, indicating transmission at community level.  As of 07 March 2022, Efate and Offshore Islands have moved to Alert Level 3 (Very High) large scale community transmission. Ten (10) new active cases have been reported in areas of Port Vila. Other parts of Vanuatu remain at alert level 0 (Low).  At Alert Level 3, all schools are closed for operation;    Source:   https://archive.ph/IGSHD

All provinces of Vanuatu are now on Alert Level 3 given reports of cases or movement of contact of cases in the six provinces of Vanuatu.    42 new confirmed cases have been reported in the last 24 hours, 27 on Efate island, Shefa province and 15 on Santo island, Sanma province.
